characters: SHIP PULLING INTO NEW YORK HARBOR
INT, SMALL, SOPHISTICATED BOSTON NIGHT CLUB

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: Flash! I have some great news for us mere men, Nickie Ferrante, the famous man among women, is going out of circulation! This big dame hunter will not scatter his shots any more. This time it's marriage. He sailed today from Europe, and Lois Clarke will be at the gangplank in New York palpitating for him. Six hundred million bucks - and lovely Lois, too. Oh, Brother! For six hundred million bueks I'd ma: an ostrich! (How much time've I got? :

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH TV NEWS' COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: In contrast to the American the Frenchman is very suave.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: (in French) Nickie Ferrante, the master in the art of making love.- the man who knows how to love them and leave them happy - has finally decided to try a new ad- venture for him...marriage! The fortunate lady is Miss Lois Clarke, the American heiress to a fortune of six hundred million American dollars. Mon Dieu, how much would that be in francs? (Nickle Derrante, le maitre de l'art d'aimer, l'homme qui sait les aimer et les quitte heureuses a finallement dedide’ de tenter une adventure pour lui toute neuve - le mariage! L'heureuse élue, heureuse et fortunée n'est autre que Miss Lois Clarke, L'heritiere Americaine de six cent millions de dollars - American dollars - Mon Dieu comblen cela” ferait-il en francs?...)

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH TV NEWSCASTER
dialogues.text: In contrast to the feverish tempo of the American and the suave Frenchman, he and his broad "A" take a leisurel and rather bored attitude.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH NEWSCASTER
dialogues.text: As I view the news - here's a rather choice tidbit -- Nickie Ferrante sails tonight to enter into matrimony with one of America's -- er -- industrial nobility -- rock and gravel I believe --- (he peers closely at news sheet) w-Ah---Miss Lois Clarke (long pause while he scans the pages. As boredom sets in) we-~there you have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passengers are strolling in evening dress, having their after dinner smokes on the balmy deck as the camera trucks up to the entrance to.the ship's interior as a page boy steps onto the deck, takes another look at the name on his list, reflects interest and pride in his mission, takes a deep breath and. calls out:

dialogues.speaker: PAGE BOY
dialogues.text: Signore Ferrante?

dialogues.text: No. The man, with his lady friend, exits as the boy turns and calls again:

dialogues.speaker: PAGE BOY

dialogues.speaker: PAGE BOY
dialogues.text: Signore Ferrante?

dialogues.text: No -- is he on board? The boy grins as he goes on down the deck, calling: Cont.  723 6 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: PAGE BOY
dialogues.text: Signore Ferrante! Signore Ferrante! (stops at stairway and looks up questioningly) Signore Ferrante? Nickle comes down the steps and stops.

dialogues.speaker: PAGE BOY

dialogues.speaker: SECOND WOMAN
dialogues.text: Something sizzling!

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: I'll have to postpone this pleasure until later - I'm wanted on the telephone---if you will excuse me--- He bows and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Gabriella, I didn't dream you eared so much -- I considered myself your plaything --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriella is lying on her bed, scantily clad in sheer negligee. She is very angry and volatile. GABR. (slight accent) How could you speak of love to me -- say the things you did - and you about to be married? Do you remember what you whispered when I gave you the cigarette case? :

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Of course! -- I said -- hello, hello - can you hear me, Gabriella? If believe we're disconnected -- operator -- INT, GABRIELLA'S BOUDOIR -- CLOSE SHOT’ GABRIELLA She knows this is a ruse. She picks up a paper Ikmife.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLA
dialogues.text: We are not disconnected! I have in my hand a knife - I wish it were in your back!

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE IN PHONE BOOTH
dialogues.text: He smiles somewhat cynically and hangs up. Then discovers he is without his cigarette case. He looks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three women are peering in at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Nickle comes out of the booth, a large man and his wif come bounding into the scene.

dialogues.speaker: HATHAWAY
dialogues.text: . (extending his hand) Oh, Mr. Ferrante. My name's Hathaway. Ned Hathaway. This is my wife, Mrs. Hathaway. We sure are: pleased to be traveling with you...

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: (mumbling) I am delighted....

dialogues.speaker: HATHAWAY
dialogues.text: (going right on) We were getting up a game of bridge and Mrs, Hathaway and I were wondering if you would care to join us. My sister Florence is traveling with us and she could be the fourth hand...

dialogues.speaker: . NICKIE
dialogues.text: You wouldn't want me. I cheat, Ee hurries off, leaving the Hathaways staring after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 an

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nickie is discovered taking a walk. He passes an interior porthole -- sees something - moves closer and calls o.s.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon. A beautiful face appears at the opposite side of the port hole. The porthole makes a lovely frame for the beautiful face. This is Terry McKay.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: I notice you have my cigarette case.

dialogues.speaker: . TERRY
dialogues.text: I might as well confess, I'm a jewel thief.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: (disbelieving) I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: All right, then, I was returning it to the purser, I found it in the -- wait a minute -- how do I lmow it's yours?

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: (impressed) There is an inscription to me on the inside.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: She opens the case,

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (reading) To Nickalo -- Terry looks at him with slightly arched eyebrows, but with a serious demeanor. TERRY . Don't tell me you're the famous -- (Nickie looks embarrassed) -- I've read so much about you! Let's see, was it in Life or Look --? Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Woman's Home Companion.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: : (in mock embarrassment) Now, may I have my cigarette case?

dialogues.speaker: FEATURING TERRY
dialogues.text: She starts to read the rest of the inscription - then:

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: This is frightfully intimate. I just kmow enough French to be embar- rassed. Can you clean it up a little and tell me in effect what it says?

dialogues.text: In French?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (smiling) No, in English.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Well, it says, in effect, 'in memory ‘of three wonderful nights on La Gabriella! -- (hastily) - that's the name of her yacht. (nodding) I guess that's you all right. She hands him the cigarette case. TWO SHOT FROM NICKIE'S ANGLE ‘ He studies her a long moment. Her face is still dead serious.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Did you write the song 'I'LL NEVER

dialogues.speaker: SMILE AGAIN
dialogues.text: Terry's manner softens and she gives him an infectious smile. Cont.

dialogues.text: 19 Cont. She humorously shakes her head negatively and exits.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: No -- but I may write one called

dialogues.speaker: "MOON OVER LA GABRIELLA."
dialogues.text: (abruptly) Do you think it will ever take th Place of night baseball? . . Nickie watches her off, very much intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING TOWARD DOOR
dialogues.text: Nickie enters, gees through door, looks around, then . disappears inside as camera moves forward along windows Camera stops as Nickie comes out of door and looks around deck for Terry. Then he paces back and forth. comes out from inside and watches him pace a moment.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: What's the matter - did you lose it again? She grins and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: : I must talk to someone.

dialogues.text: No -- you have an honest face, I ean trust you, can't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 723 20 Cont. al 22

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: . (taking her arm) Come with me. He starts leading her to door as she speaks:

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: “Yes, but the captain has an honest face, too -- why don't you tell him your troubles? They exit inside.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Nickie and Terry come around the corner and start forward as camera moves back with them. Halfway down, he turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Shall we go to your cabin or mine?

dialogues.text: (as they walk on) Maybe mine is closer - it's just - (steps a little ahead of her and indicates off)

dialogues.speaker: TERRY

dialogues.speaker: TERRY

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT

dialogues.text: Oo

dialogues.speaker: TERRY -

dialogues.text: Terry McKay. Terry McKay, and I'm traveling alone. (as he starts into room) Was that by any chance what was troubling you?

dialogues.text: (stops and turns to her) (walks back and looks around) Oh, this is fine -- You saved my life, you know - I was bored to death -- I haven't seen one attractive girl on this boat since we left -- not one. It's terrible -- it's not for me -- Life should be bright -- it should be beautiful and bubbly, like champagne. I got scared - I said to myself "Don't beautiful women travel anymore? Evidently not.' And then I saw you and it was all right -- I was saved - I hope. (offering her case) Yes. Cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: No thanks. (walks back toward chair) Have you been getting results with a line like that? (sitting on arm of chair) Or would I be surprised?

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: (sitting down) If you were surprised it would surprise me. Cont.

dialogues.text: 22 Cont.1

dialogues.text: That sounds like a nasty crack, I . ! could make a few too if I felt like it. |

/ 22 Cont.3 ‘ . He examines the picture again.

dialogues.text: (a vague gesture )

dialogues.text: And he said I didn't belong in a place like that...he said that... huh?

dialogues.text: Well, he said that - er - well, he said I belonged on Park Avenue with a lovely view of... of him? NICKIE

dialogues.speaker: TERRY

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE

dialogues.speaker: TERRY

dialogues.text: . Oh, yes -- . | (ug) ‘ NICKIE | . . (taking plate out and : pulling inside out and walking back to rail) Takes very clear pictures, eh?

dialogues.text: Nickie comes. up ‘the steps and sees a little boy hanging from the beams.

dialogues.text: How about you, sir? You're a big man. Would you be so kind as to --

dialogues.text: (quickly) I'm not a performer - I'm ill at ease, in public.

dialogues.speaker: HATHAWAY
dialogues.text: (significantly) Everybody understands that but that's the fun of it! I'm going to do a turn myself and Lord knows I'm a real amateur. Won't you just appear and say a few words and give all the women folks a thri11?

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but ----

dialogues.speaker: HATHAWAY
dialogues.text: I am too, because it would help to correct an impression that's sort of going around.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: The passengers think you're a little snooty, Nickie -- let me talk to him, Mr. Hathaway,

dialogues.speaker: HATHAWAY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss McKay. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A-54 Cont.1 Hathaway exits. . 1

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: If I work out a little routine for the . two of us, would you do it with me? NICKIE . So the passengers think I'm a snob! ‘

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Let's show them how wrong they are.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Hmmm - will it take a lot of rehearsing?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: We wouldn't want to do anything that. wasn's perfect,

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: You're so right,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the finish of their number, Nickle and Terry exit. @ Applause breaks out, Hathaway enters, applauding and | gestures for them to return for a bow. When they do not reappear he crosses to the exit and looks off. He turns back to the audience with a comical expression.

dialogues.speaker: HATHAWAY
dialogues.text: Well, it looks like they're not coming back -- they just kept going -- so, as I always say, 'The Show Must Go On.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hears the orchestra vamping in the background, looks at his list to see who's on next, .

dialogues.speaker: HATHAWAY
dialogues.text: (heartily) . : Ho, ho - that's me! He starts singing a comedy number. 55 our 56 our

dialogues.speaker: EXT, DECK
dialogues.text: Nickie and Terry enter, They are ecstatically happy from their experiences entertaining the passengers. Nickie has her by the hand. :

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: I don't know when I've had so much fun.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: The whole trip has been a memorable one for me, A silent beat, Both stare at the ‘wake of the boat.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: (reading her mind) I know what you mean -- and I talked to the captain about it,

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Yes - and what did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he couldn't turn the boat around -- there might be some minor objections. Most of the passengers are homesick -- they're anxious to get back to their loved ones,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see where it would be a problem - just cruising around with the two of us, . There is another silence and Terry crosses over to the rail, leans on it in meditation, Nickie watches her from a distance. From offscene we hear the singing of "Auld Lang Syne" coming from the concert hall (presumably the concert is over). Nickie walks Slowly over to Terry.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (as she senses he is about to speak) If you say, 'A Penny For Your Thoughts! I'll jump overboard.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: (coming close to her) This is our last night. Tomorrow morning -- New York,

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Yes, Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Will he be waiting?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: At the dock -- and she?

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: At the gangplank, Another silence. They brood a moment. The music of "Auld Lang Syne" continues in background,

dialogues.speaker: NI
dialogues.text: (abruptly) : You know, I've never had a job in my life.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: In that article I read, it said something about you being in the war,

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: That wasn't employment I sought. (then as an after- thought, he salutes) I never cultivated a taste for work. There were so many other things to do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about that... (long pause) What did you ‘say?

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: You did, too, You said that I was very fond of expensive things - furs, diamonds...stuff like that...

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Did I say that?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Pink champagne - that's the kind of life we're both used to...It might be a little difficault to... (she thinks) What does beer taste like?

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Bitter. Cont,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 57 Cont.1 She nods. Silence again. They both meditate.

dialogues.speaker: NI
dialogues.text: (slowly) Of course, they're not absolutely necessary, Diamonds, I mean,

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: No, not absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: There must be all kinds of people - everywhere...who are perfectly happy, and they never saw a diamond.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Yes, there must be.

dialogues.speaker: NI
dialogues.text: (solemnly) You'd only have to insure them, and you know what a bother that is - insurance people knocking at your door, and asking you to fill out all Kinds of forms...

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I hate filling out forms.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: . TERRY
dialogues.text: I guess you and I have been spoiled...

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Yes, we're used to the best of every- thing... Pause. In b.g., music ends: Applause. Another number starts.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: My father used to say... ‘It's a funny thing - but the things we like best are either illegal, immoral, or fatten- ing. 1 .

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Alexander Wolcott said that, too.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: He stole 1% from my father. . Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 Cont.2 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bé

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Did your father drink beer?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: He drank anything.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: You know - nobody gets younger... No, they don't,

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Sooner or: later - they look in the mirror and say...

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (finishing it for hin You've had it, brother. You missed the train.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: I hate missing. trains.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Me, too,

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: I wonder what your father would have thought of me - not working one day in my whole life...

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (t: gZ to console him Just because you haven't...

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: (finishing it for her) It doesn't mean...I couldn't. - (a pause) What's that section of the paper called? In back - with the small print...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help wanted.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Of course, it might take a little time - say, six months...to find out if... Cont.

dialogues.speaker: . TERRY
dialogues.text: If what?

dialogues.speaker: NI
dialogues.text: (sweating) Well - if I worked hard enough and long enough...say for six months... where would you be?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (looking at him) What are you trying to say?

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: (having difficulty with it) I'm trying to say that it would take me six months to find out if I could afford to buy my wife a bottle of beer.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Oh, Nickie. That's about the nicest - (she breaks off) I'm going to turn in.. (as she fixes his tie) Will you let .me think about it, and tell you in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: . (holding her) It's going to be a long night.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: For me, too. They turn from the rail and walk away, holding hands - then separate as he starts for steps. Terry.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Marriage is a very serious step for @ girl like me.

dialogues.speaker: ' NICKIE
dialogues.text: Yes, I know.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Do you like children?

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, I do. smiles and exits down steps as Nickie goes up other steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 our

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 making its way into New York Harbor. Terry hurries to Nickie, who is looking around waiting for her, She has on a mink coat with practically nothing underneath.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Nickie --

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: I was so worried --

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: .T Raven't even had time to get dressed and I didn't get to sleep until 5,

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: (quickly) I didn't sleep at all.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: If everything goes all right for both of us - in six months - I mean ~ that would be in July -- NICKIE . July - yes - where will we meet? Terry stops and looks out over the rail. The Empire State Building looms in view, standing high above the New York skyline.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (pointing to the Empire State Building) What about the Empire State Building? (Nickie nods) Darling, it's the tallest building in the world. You couldn't miss that -- itts the nearest thing to heaven we have in New York --

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: What time? What floor?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Five o'clock -- the top of the building -- the 102nd floor - and be sure you take the elevator --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, I will. Cont. 723

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4g 59 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: A-59
dialogues.text: 60 61 62 63 64 65 66 Terry runs out, leaving Nickie looking after her for a moment, then he turns back and looks up at the top of the Empire State Building.

DOCK - CLOSE SHOT - KENNETH IN CROWD - Day spots Terry on the upper deck and waves and grins at her.

dialogues.text: Miss Clark, let us have a picture, please. He. snaps a picture as she poses - she turns back to wave at Nickie. .

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: (belligerently) What is all this? LOIs (a gush) Oh, darling, didn't I mention it? The TV people have just been hound ing me to death for an interview. We've sort of become this year's version of Grace Kelly and Prince What 's-His-Name?

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: (aryly) Prince Rainier of Monaco -- very nice fellow. Loris Well, anyway, I said yes if they'd give a handsome donation to my favorite charity. You don't mind, do you, darling? It's for a good cause.

dialogues.speaker: . NICKIE
dialogues.text: (sourly) 4m I going to be married = or inaugurated? LorIs (taking his arm) Now, darling, don't pout. We'll have all the privacy we want - later... She draws him toward a large overstuffed chair. Nickie steps over a TV cable as though it were a s LoIs nake. Nickie, dear, this is Mr. Lewis -- Robert Lewis -- who is going to interview us. As Nickie and Lewis shake hands like two fighters:

dialogues.text: a rather lavish apartment with an air of having been re- cently redecorated. French windows go out to a balcony. Center we see Terry's trunk - with the steamship labels on it - still unopened. Terry is with Gladys, her colored maid. She has a newspaper in her hand. Cont.

dialogues.text: shooting toward rail where Terry and Nickie are stand- ing, separated by four passengers. Terry is looking down, waving at Kenneth while Nickie is busy looking down at Lois.

dialogues.text: spots Terry on the upper deck and waves and grins at her. EXT. DECK - CLOSE SHOT - TERRY - DAY ‘ now looks from Kenneth to Nickie and nods, "Yes, that's he" then she looks down at Lois.

dialogues.text: with photographers aroynd her.

dialogues.text: ‘Miss Clarke, let us have a picture, please,

dialogues.text: 66 Cont. _ but is embarrassed when all passengers look at her, so she turns from rail and exits. Nickie gets a little fussed and he exits too. O s

dialogues.text: Lois is standing in the crowd looking up toward Nickie. ) Photographers and TV News Commentators are hovering aroun her, asking for pictures. She finally breaks away and . hurries up the steps to the gangplank where Nickie has just stopped. Terry can be seen among people behind them. LoIs Nickie, darling. . |

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Lois! | : (kissing both cheeks) | . : I'm so glad to see you -- , LOIs . . I'm so glad to see you = did yo ' have a nice trip? '

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: (as Terry comes up behind them) — | Yes -< - !

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Hold it for a still, please -- : (they kiss)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: : Thank you! That's fine -- just one | more, please -- . (they put cheeks together) Thank you -- just one more -- just | one more, please -- Lors (holding his hands out ) Will this do?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (trying to get between them) : I beg your pardon - I'm awfully sorry | | - if you'll excuse me - I have an appointment - (she exits)

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Just one more -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 723 They decline and exit together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 74 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: . (indicating furniture) ° eeMr. Kenneth had the whole apart- ment redone. He even fixed up the terrace just the way you wanted it - and that's new wallpaper. He said, "Gladys, you an' me's gonna make this. place...! .

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (half-heartedly) . It's lovely, Gladys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, honey? You don't | seem too excited comin' home... . (who isn't) - Oh, I am, Gladys. I love the wall- paper - the furniture, too. Mr. Bredley's very kind...
( Kind? Honey, he's a double gentle- —— man. He just gimme a big fat raise.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (distracted, wandering about apartment) Did he? That's wonderful, Glady. Save your money.

dialogues.speaker: . GLADYS
dialogues.text: | I'd have more if my horses ran faster.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (glancing at clock on mantel) Is that clock right?

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: It's always been.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Would you put the TV on? Channel h, I think.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: as Gladys, a bit mystified, crosses to set and turns it on. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cont. 723 on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 723 75 Cont. 76 wearing - in which she got off the boat.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Since when did you start watching this thing in the afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I read that at 2:30 there's an inter- view with Lois Clarke and that man | she's marrying...Ferrante, isn't that his name? I thought I'd watch it.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: (at the TV set) Ain't that the fella Mr. Winchell calls 'The Big Dame Hunter?! (a hillbilly show comes on. Gladys gestures at the singer with the guitar) That him?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (indignant) } Of course not. |

dialogues.speaker: TOWARD DOOR
dialogues.text: as Kenneth opens door - with his own key, of course. Gladys turns the sound down. Kenneth closes the door, crosses quickly to Terry, kisses her. Gladys (with a grin) exits. .

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: (the kiss over) H'm...remind me to ask you later about that kiss. Maybe you're just out of practice - I hope. He notices her unpacked trunk. Then the dress she's

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: . (his eyebrows up) I thought you'd be all unpacked and in something...uh...comfortable,.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (determined) We have a lot to talk about, Ken. I think better in this outfit:

dialogues.speaker: KENNE'
dialogues.text: (hushing her) Baby, let me talk first...then you won't have to say a word. I'm free! Cont.  77

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 723 76 Cont. 55 KENNETH (Cont.) (he waits for her to be happy about it. She isn't) My wife and her lawyers took every- thing but my right arm, but... (holding her) eesyou're worth it. I'm on Cloud 10. On cloud nine they don't know what happiness is. Know why? They ain't got you.

dialogues.speaker: PAST TERRY AND KENNETH
dialogues.text: as Gladys comes in.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: eeeThat program's on now... (a take) Program?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (quickly) Oh - Gladys means the TV...You know - _ the Clarke-Ferrante thing...they're being interviewed...Would you turn: up the set, darling? He nods - crosses to set, adjusts the picture and sound. (kneeling) He was on the same boat with you, wasn't he? (Terry nods) , Did you meet him? (Terry nods) Was he charming? (Terry nods) Fascinating? (Terry nods) Irresistible? Terry doesn't nod. Ken is contrite, goes to her, puts his arm around her. .

dialogues.speaker: KENNETE
dialogues.text: Sorry. I withdraw the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O s By 78 CLOSE SHOT - TV SET - DAY -Nickie, Lois Clarke and Robert Lewis. Nickie is seated in a large overstuffed chair, Lois sits on the arm stroki his hair fondly. Nickie is trying hard to look like a man about to be happily married. The scene is Miss Clark's sumptuous drawing room.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Many marriages break up over financial difficulties, but I'm sure that won't be one of your --

dialogues.speaker: INT, LOIS' DRAWING ROOM
dialogues.text: Lors i (cutting in) No, no «= that won't be one of our problems. Lewis attempts to inject a little light humor. He ad- 3 dresses Nickie.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS .
dialogues.text: Is this your first experience with connubial bliss? .

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: Would you mind rephrasing the ‘question? LoIs Darling, he means is this your first . experience with marriage?

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: : (looking at Lois) With marriage? (dryly, to Lewis) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (being witty) Do you intend to support your wife in the manner... (he looks over drawing room) esto which she's accustomed?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY AND KENNETH
dialogues.text: watching. Terry holds her breath.

dialogues.speaker: THE TV SCREEN
dialogues.text: Nickie has considered the question.

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: I'm going to make every effort to. Reaction from Lois. LoIs (a bit astonished) Doing what, darling?

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: I'm going to start painting again eeeand make a living for my wife... Lois! eyebrows go up. She looks at the wall behind the couch on which they are sitting. Camera pans - the wall is covered with art masterpieces. : Lors But, darling - we already have a house full of paintings...Picasso, Van Gogh, Matisse.... er geet ROOM - FULL SHOT - NICKIE, LOIS AND ROBERT LEWI ot

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: (his jaw a little hard) I'm still going to paint. Lors (beginning to burn) In heaven's name, why? You'll be too busy, and besides - I'm allergic to turpentine. Nervously he takes out'his cigarette case, removes a cig- arette, then offers the case to Lois. Lois starts to take a cigarette, sees the inscription, tries to read it. Nickie closes the case so hastily that he almost catches Lois' finger in it. Lewis looks slightly uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: LEW
dialogues.text: (quickly) When is the marriage set for, Miss Clarke? LoIs Oh, as soon as possible...in about --

dialogues.speaker: NICKIE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Six months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: thrilled...with Kenneth watching her closely now, begin- ning to guess...and then back to:

dialogues.speaker: TV SCREEN
dialogues.text: Lois is furious. LoIs (all her hackles up) Six months! If you think I'm going to wait... Nickie pantomimes the television camera watching them - and Lois catches herself, but not entirely. She is still burning as:

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (doing it fast) And that, ladies and gentlemen, concludes our interview with this charming couple...we will now turn you back to George Easton... LorIs Are we off the air now? LEwIs Not yet. Embarrassed, Lois puts her hand to her mouth. As the screen blacks out we still hear voices for ea moment as though the sound man hasn't gotten his cue to cut off - including an irate exclamation from Lois. .

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: with Kenneth turning off the set. Terry in background.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: (slowly - his back to her) Well - I just fell off Cloud lo.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (unhappily) Oh, Ken. If I'd only known before... I could have saved you so much heart- ache...and a lot of money, too, She crosses to him. He looks at her, still not believing it.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: ‘ Darling, it just doesn't make sense. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 86 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: . TERRY
dialogues.text: (miserably) I know.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: You must be slightly out of your mind. .

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETE
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I'm going back to Boston until

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: Until he what? He'll never be able 7 to support youl ) (coming close) ( . Terry, listen to me. I want to marry Sue you...I should've asked you a long time ago. It's my fault, but it's not too late, is it? It can't be too late...Terry, look at me. Can't you see I'm in love?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (looking at him) Uh-huh. So am I. She crosses abruptly to the balcony, opens one of the glass doors, As it swings open we see the top of the Empire State Building reflected in the glass. As Terry stands looking up: |

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: singing a lively Irish folk song.

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: watching her.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: She finishes singing the last 16 bars of the song, bows and leaves to resounding applause.

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: Terry comes from the night club amid the sound of applaus The manager is beaming at her.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: How'm I doing, Boss?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: That noise is applause, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Oh, maybe they're applauding the chef.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: No, that's for you.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: . You don't know what that Boston applause means to me. It hasn't been easy. I'm very grateful to you and... (she nods toward the night club)

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: I'd like to talk a long contract.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Six months.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: That's not a long time.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes it is! As the applause continues, Terry goes back into the club, camera panning her.

dialogues.speaker: INT, NIGHT CLUB

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (seeing the remorse in his eyes, the knowledge, tries to smile) Darling...don't look at me like that... . (warmly) It was nobody's fault but my own...I was looking up into the sky... . (smiling, her eyes moistening) You see, it was the nearest thing there was to heaven...because you were there. . As Nickie's arms go about her, she clings to him, tears of happiness and sureness in her eyes as she smiles shakily, joyously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If) you can paint...I can walk...the world can turn upside down...ife... The chorus comes into the scoring, singing "Love Affair."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog, lying down, looks off, his ears perk up and he starts running. Camera pans with him. As the dog reaches the entrance to the villa we. see Nickie carrying Terry over the threshold, and we do not know whether or not Terry is able to walk again.
